Event.name: Besieging
Event.definition:
<def-root>An <fen>Assailant</fen>, a group of armed forces, surrounds the <fen>Victim</fen>, a military location and the people within it, in an attempt to cut the <fen>Victim</fen> off from the outside, with the goal of either forcing their surrender or weakening them so that an invasion would be successful. A successful siege is often followed by the <fen>Assailant</fen> taking control of (the land held by) the <fen>Victim</fen>.
<ex><fex name="tim">Towards the end of the summer</fex>, <fex name="ass">a great English host</fex> <t>besieged</t> <fex name="vic">the Danish fort of Tempsford</fex> and took it, killing the last Danish king of East Anglia.</ex></def-root>

Arg.name: Assailant
Arg.definition: <def-root>The <fen>Assailant</fen> is a group of armed forces (or, metonymically, their commander or the organization they represent) that encircles, surrounds, or otherwise cuts off the Beseiged in an attempt to force surrender.</def-root>

Arg.name: Victim
Arg.definition: <def-root>The <fen>Victim</fen> is the fortification or geopolitical entity that is being attacked.</def-root>

Arg.name: Manner
Arg.definition: <def-root>Any description of the event which is not covered by more specific FEs, including epistemic modification (probably, presumably, mysteriously), force (hard, softly), secondary effects (quietly, loudly), and general descriptions comparing events (the same way). It may also indicate salient characteristics of an <fen>Assailant</fen> that also affect the action (presumptuously, coldly, deliberately, eagerly, carefully). </def-root>

Arg.name: Means
Arg.definition: <def-root>An intentional action performed by the <fen>Assailant</fen> that accomplishes the assault. </def-root>

Arg.name: Place
Arg.definition: <def-root>This FE identifies the place where the <fen>Assailant</fen> makes an assault on the <fen>Victim</fen>. </def-root>

Arg.name: Purpose
Arg.definition: <def-root>This FE identifies the purpose for which an <fen>Assailant</fen> attacks the <fen>Victim</fen>.</def-root>

Arg.name: Source
Arg.definition: <def-root>The starting-point of the motion of the <fen>Assailant</fen> or projectiles of the <fen>Assailant</fen> as they move toward the the <fen>Place</fen> that the <fen>Victim</fen> is occupying in the attack. In prepositional phrases, the prepositional object expresses the starting point of motion. With particles, the starting point of motion is understood from context.</def-root>

Arg.name: Time
Arg.definition: <def-root>This FE identifies the time when the <fen>Assailant</fen> attacks the <fen>Victim</fen>.</def-root>

Arg.name: Weapon
Arg.definition: <def-root>An entity used by the <fen>Assailant</fen> to cause damage to the <fen>Victim</fen>.</def-root>

Arg.name: Path
Arg.definition: <def-root>The <fen>Path</fen> refers to (a part of) the ground over which the <fen>Assailant</fen> travels. </def-root>

Arg.name: Duration
Arg.definition: <def-root>The length of time that the <fen>Victim</fen> is under attack from the <fen>Assailant</fen></def-root>

lexUnit.name: besiege.v
lexUnit.definition: COD: surround (a place) with armed forces in order to capture it or force its surrender.

lexUnit.name: siege.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: a military operation in which enemy forces surround a town or building, cutting off essential supplies, with the aim of compelling the surrender of those inside.

lexUnit.name: invest.v
lexUnit.definition: COD: surround (a place) in order to besiege or blockade it.

lexUnit.name: investment.n
lexUnit.definition: FN: the act or process of laying siege to.

lexUnit.name: besiegement.n
lexUnit.definition: FN: the act or process of besieging.

lexUnit.name: encirclement.n
lexUnit.definition: FN: completely surrounding so as to prevent escape.
